snippet: Each year, an estimated 25,000 babies in the United States receive a diagnosis of microcephaly, an abnormally small head, but prognoses are hard to predict.
abstract: Zika virus outbreak in Brazil and South and Central America has drawn global attention in part because of possible link to microcephaly, birth deformity that has mystified experts for decades; microcephaly is ailment that has no treatment, no cure and unclear prognosis, and while disorder may augur future brain damage, it is not necessarily indication of neurological problem.

byline.contributor: Donald G. McNeil Jr. contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Each year, an estimated 25,000 babies in the United States receive a diagnosis of microcephaly, an abnormally small head, but prognoses are hard to predict.

headline.main: Microcephaly, Spotlighted by Zika Virus, Has Long Afflicted and Mystified
headline.print_headline: Ailment Linked to Zika Epidemic Has Long Afflicted and Mystified

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
